Caption: Fig. 1. a) Workflow as rendered currently using toolkits such as GraphViz. b) We propose to replace the textual labels with glyphs, while allowing interactive access to detailed descriptions. This makes it easy to gain an overview, search components and compare workflows. The screenshot shows a prototype developed within ISAcreator, a system for capturing biological experiment metadata.
Fig. 2. A systematic process for creating glyph based representations.

Table 1. A fragment of the input document passed to the taxonomy gen- eration algorithm. Schemes are grouped by common names preceding the semi-colon, e.g. S1:On Material refers to schema 1 and On Material is the classification.
Fig. 3. The classification algorithm arranged the classification schemes in the above order.

Table 2. Perceptual strength of different visual channels based on levels of organization studied by Bertin[7] and Green[17], ‘popout’ effect studied extensively in psychology [61, 15, 31, 7, 17, 63, 55, 38, 39], and hierarchy effect studied by Navon [35] and Love [30]. The summary strength of each channel is estimated and it should be considered in conjunction with application-specific conventions and metaphors.

Perceptual strength of different visual channels based on levels of organization studied by Bertin[7] and Green[17], ‘popout’ effect studied extensively in psychology [61, 15, 31, 7, 17, 63, 55, 38, 39], and hierarchy effect studied by Navon [35] and Love [30]. The summary strength of each channel is estimated and it should be considered in conjunction with application-specific conventions and metaphors.

Fig. 6. Formation of the final glyph design. Top level items require the greatest visual power. It is important to be able to distinguish each of the processes based on their parent level in the taxonomy. Distinguish- able global shapes provide the difference between IOs (circles) and pro- cesses (squares with pointed bottom to indicate directionality).
